reviewText: Sleeping Dogs questions your sense of duty and belonging throughout the game. For the first 5 hours I didn't get to handle a gun which is not what I expected. Instead I was Kung Fu Fighting. This game had a really nice mixed gameplay of fist to fist combat and gunplay. The graphics were quite horrible in console, but this game on PC highest settings with the high res pack makes this game look a lot more beautiful. In other hands the story was breathtaking, it immersed me from feeling Wei Shen's side of being a cop and a triad. The huge dilemma he faced with his duty or belonging. He had a family and a sense of home with his gang, but he also had a job to bring them down.\nOverall the story was amazing, the graphics were good but the edges of the models are evident but their textures are realistic and the gameplay is quite thrilling especially with the brutal melee kills.

reviewText:
Hmm... where do I start with this game? Well for starters, this overlooked title is frequently compared to the GTA franchise. So what does this game have to offer?

What I like about this game:
- The setting of Hong Kong, loosely based off of the real Hong Kong that is...
- The hand-to-hand combat with interactivity of the environment to even the odds a bit (and because it looks fancy).
- The story following an undercover police officer.
- The protagonist Wei Shen and the characters he interacts with.
- The colorful environment making Hong Kong feel active (especially the night market)

Stuff that gave me mixed feelings or have no opinion on:
- The AI: sometimes their behavior get pretty wonky at times, but nothing majorly broken with them
- The side activities: they're okay if not a little underwhelming since there isn't a lot of stuff to do aside from side quests. For me, the two gambling activities are kind of a waste of your time unless you want a method to toss your money away more quickly.
- Environmental glitches: I encountered about one or two bugs, with one of them involving a wire attached to a security camera floating in the middle of a parking lot, but nothing major.
- The protagonist Wei Shen never speaking a single word in Cantonese (he said one word in Cantonese in the wheels of fury dlc, much to my suprise). Honestly it confuses me a little bit, but that's just a minor complaint. I'm just going to assume he just has a preference to strictly speaking english anyway.
- Guns: yes, yes, nothing's fun without gunplay, but obtaining guns is a little different than what you would expect from GTA. While gunplay is pretty fun, there is no way of purchasing firearms or ammunition so the only way you can get them outside of story missions (and occasionally DLC) is to do it the hard way: steal them from the HKPD. Completing the story will get you a golden Desert Eagle for you to use.
- The map size: a bit small for an open world game, but it's tolerable.
- The mini map: most of the time, directions for way points work, but there was one area that partially breaks the GPS and tells you to go around in circles until you disobey it.


What I didn't like:
- The ending: It didn't bother me too much, but I kinda wish you could become a member of the Triads full-time or stay loyal to the Hong Kong Police Department.
- The DLC: personally I think most of them don't really offer much, but I think a few of them are probably worth purchasing, especially if they're on sale.
- The second to last story mission: specifically it is the quick-time event on the scaffolding where button mashing is required. The reason why I hate that sequence is because there is a programing error that if you rapidly button mash, you will fail regardless of how fast you press the spacebar. How to get past it is to find a steady rhythm and keep the rhythm for about 20 - 30 seconds. (Note that it took me 10 minutes to figure out what was going on and go to the forums to look for help. I know, it's really sad to admit that it took me that long for me to figure it out)
- Animation quality: they didn't put a lot of effort into animation outside of the official cutscenes. They put effort into lip-syncing and movement in the cutscenes, but didn't even try to put any effort outside of that, althought when it comes to movement like walking and running, they are just fine. (I should note that they semi-locked" the camera to make sure you don't see Wei's face
date: and when you do see it
recommended: it's very obvious they didn't even bother)\n- Camera angles: my main pet peev comes from driving when you want to go reverse
hoursPlayed:
the camera automatically rotates around the car and I'd rather do it manually because it feels really disorienting to have the game do it for me.

What will kick most people in the teeth:
- The lack of a multiplayer: the game has a social hub for you to compare scores with your friends
voteText: but some people like me will not care about numbers and might be upset that there is no physical multiplayer to play with your friends.\n\nDespite my complaints
helpfulPercent: this game has plenty to offer and is definitely worth the current price tag and deserves more attention that it currently has."

reviewText:
Rating: 10/10
Story review: Realistic, breath-taking view of Hong Kong mirrored into the game creates an excellent open-world experience that is yet to be chalenged by the likes of GTA.
The choreographed fighting, acting, driving and cut scenes are above average, showcasing what is possible when developers take game mechanics seriously and invest in it.
The game has a short learning path, even for new comers. You'll get thrown right into action from the first scene, and the nostalgic storyline will keep begging you for a repeat of the story once you're done.

Visuals and system requirements: The visuals are stellar, and you will not need to break a bank to build a rig that can play this game. Simply put, if you can play Tomb Raider on Medium settings with DirectX11 features turned on, you'll blaze through this game without breaking a sweat.

Stereoscopic 3D via AMD HD3D works out of the box if you have an AMD HD 5000+ GPU connected to a 3D capable monitor via HDMI 1.4a. Depending on your setup, you may need a 3D driver such as Tridef 3D to play it in 3D mode.

Personally, I had a blast playing the game and would recommend it highly.

reviewText: GTA: China, or so I Imagined Sleeping Dogs like that when i first heard about it but it's so much more than that. Of course it is like GTA in china in a way, but it doesn't fail in a storytelling like GTA 4 did. The game takes major influence from movies The Departed and Infernal Affairs where the line between friend and foe gets blurred and character loyalties and movies are questioned. The protagonist, Wei Shen is an undercover cop in Hong Kong who sworn uphold the law and bring criminals to justice but by virtue of being undercover which is also a gangster comiting very real acts of of crime. He has a personal vendetta against drug pushing triads for what they did to his sister and he sworn to take them down. It's a game about dealing with conflicting aspects of self. And what is interesting you don't have to chose between those aspects. It's a game about living with and reconsiling the fact that you have theese identities. The best straightforward example of this is you get 2 different EXP bars after each mission, the triad and cop. Triad exp fills with every kill you make, the more brutal the better, headshots, explosions fill up that bar while cop exp punish you for being clumsy or killing hostage etc. it implies that Wei is a good cop at the begining of the mission and going down morally doing his job. It's a game where protagonist doing the triad and cop things and he has to live up with consequences and it's show in game every time Wei goes to sleep.\nI think it's a good game and worth your attention 8/10.

reviewText:
This game was brilliant. Much better than other titles that Square Enix has made that are not Final Fantasy such as Just Cause which has serious audio syncing problems.
Combat system closely related to that of Batman Arkham Asylum and Arkam City. graphics are quite impressive.

But besides the great fighting mechanics, the endless amount of things that you can do in Hong Kong, the customisation with clothes and the many many cars there are to purchase and show off. What is most impressive about this has to definitely be the storyline. Unlike typical games of this genre such as Grand Theft Auto and Saints Row, the main protagnanist of the game,  Wei Shen, is not just a character that comes off as just the average, out to get money and destroy stuff for the sake of it.

Wei Shen is the heart of the game. He is a well respected polie offica with the San Fransico police department that heads back to his home city, Hong Kong, to try and assist the local PD with taking down the Traids in the citty. It is immediatly obvious that your character has history with a fair amount of the people in the Traids, seeing as they use one of your oldest friends, Jackie to get Wei into the Triads to begin his undercover operation. Though as Shen gets pulled further in to the seedy underground workings of Hong Kong. It becomes more apparent that his motives of ether helping the police take down the Traids, or working with the Triads become extremely blurred.

In conclusion, as I have seen with other reviews of this game, we are all confused as to why people are not paying enough attention to this brilliant title. Yes there are a few bugs in the game, but what game doesn't. Even if you do not like the look of the game, I absolutely recommend this game just for it;s in depth and keep you on the edge of your seat" storyline."

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs is a realistic look at the undercover life in the Hong Kong Triads (organized crime) played as a third person open world game. I guess you can compare it to the Grand Theft Auto games or Saints Row games in terms of actual gameplay.

In Sleeping Dogs you’ll find yourself driving in cars for large portions of the game since the game world is actually very large. There’s a fast travel option that I didn’t even know existed until I replayed the game a couple of months ago. The combat in the game is very similar to the Batman Arkham games (strike & counter), but with no gadgets. There are also sections where you’ll use guns, but it’s about 90% hand to hand fighting.

Where the game really shines is in story. You’re an undercover cop trying to worm your way into the Triad and slowly get pulled in more and more into the life. It’s how I imagine real undercover cops experience their jobs.

Overall I give the game a thumbs up. It seems like every game I review gets a thumbs up, but that’s because if I don’t like a game, I stop playing. Steam offers a free HD textures DLC so everything looks good with the graphics turned way up.

reviewText: I think Sleeping Dogs is a really fun game.  The story is fast-paced, intense, and intriguing.  The graphics are wonderful, the atmosphere wonderful with some humor thrown in.  The music that plays when you're driving around, for the most part, is great.  Beyond stealing cars and completing missions, the combat elements are excellently done--that goes for firearms and ESPECIALLY for melee combat.  Great DLC as well.  Different outfits aren't just for vanity, but add either a challenging element (like added heat from the police) or additional combat options based off of real martial arts schools.... from drunken master, to wing chun, tai chi chuan, mui tai, mma, etc....  There are some classy and fun automobiles and the races range from easy to very challenging difficulty.  The side activities can be as fun as the main story.  You can learn how to swear in Chinese as well.\n\nThe only thing that could make this game better is actual nudity for all the hot chix you can date--and even Wei Chen... he's got a hot bod too.  Anyone make those mods yet?  If so, hit me up!  Ha.....

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs - another GTA like game. At first glance, everything is as usual: shooting, chase, mission, gangsters, police patrol, sex, drugs and rock and roll =).
But after 2 hours of the game, we find ourselves in the real Hong Kong with his daily events and people. City shows quite clearly. Victoria Peak - the beauty of which burn out like a snake. Beauty.
Beauty yacht in the Night.
Beautiful yachts, nightclubs, classical Chinese markets. All this is done really well and is exactly what if you find yourself in Hong Kong at present.
Honestly - I like many was not in China, except in Japan. I'm a fighter - karate.
And as a fighter, I can say that the fight scenes, strikes, movements are done very thoroughly. Thanks to the developers for the respect for the martial arts. Thank you also for respect for religion! Ceremonial urn, Buddha Temple, the monks - all in the game. And the plot of the game dramatically and exciting! Good cop bad.
Unfortunately events in the game are very real. War and bloodshed triad goes every day. Control of the territory, drugs, weapons. This game shows us both sides of the coin."
10 out of 10. Best game of martial arts."

reviewText:
A very good game that is the Hong Kong version of Grand Theft Auto.

In this game you are an undercover cop infiltrating the criminal gangs of Hong Kong called the Triads. Over the course of the game, the protagonist will feel attachment to the Triads and starts to have conflicting loyalties. The story is top notch and rivals that of GTA4.

Unlike GTA4, the game focuses mostly on hand-to-hand combat where you have an arsenal of kung fu moves. It is almost like the Arkham game series. But there are enough gun battles to keep things interesting.

But the story is the thing I enjoyed the most.

If you are a fan of GTA4, you will enjoy this game. It has a very good story. Highly recommended.

reviewText:
I felt compelled to write a review for Sleeping Dogs, as it is a game that gave me more bang for my buck than most ever have.  I'm a huge fan of open-world games with driving (GTA, Saints Row, Far Cry).  With that said, I 100%'d Sleeping Dogs at about 30 hours in, and my current playtime is now nearing the 118 mark.  I can count the number of games I've 100%'d on less than two hands.  So, I think the important question is, why do I still keep playing?  What caused me to learn this game inside and out, to the point where I know all the mechanics, glitches, and how to mess with every piece of AI?

The answer lies in that to me, Sleeping Dogs is just pure fun.  The melee combat is something that almost no other game has done as well, and really the only one that comes to mind is the Arkham series.  Even with Arkham, I find the combat takes too long, whereas in Sleeping Dogs it gets things just right.  It's visceral while remaining simple.  Enemies react in momentary fear to bone-crushing martial arts moves, and the protagonist Wei Shen can masterfully counter and take out hordes of gangsters.  Wei also moves around Hong Kong with basic parkour moves, as he can survive falls of impressive heights and slide over all manner of objects smoothly, if timed right.

The other aspect is driving.  Let me preface this section with two things: one, that I vastly prefer arcade style driving (if I want real driving, I'll go take my real car out), and two, the weapon-based DLC car singlehandedly has given me hours upon hours of extra time with the game.  I'll put this bluntly; if you want realistic driving, go play another game.  Ramming cars at high speeds, tearing through the Financial District with a nearly indestructible bus, and blowing out the tires that sends cars flying like a Hollywood movie... all of its is insanely fun.  Add in the DLC car that pretty much breaks the game, and it just gets hilarious how awesomely you can dominate Hong Kong.

Sleeping Dogs is far from perfect, however.  Some of the things the game does are laughably bad, like how the police are handled.  I'm not going to mince words here, the police are just terrible.  They're so bad that they're funny, like with how awful horror movies work.  The biggest issue I have is that they literally pop into an area.  You could be in a desolate alley and shoot someone, or beat up a bunch of people in a quiet street with no police anywhere nearby.. and they will literally pop in like they used a portal gun or stepped through a dimensional rift.  If they weren't so easy to shake off and mess with, this would have ruined any sense of immersion the game had.

While I thoroughly enjoyed the story with a satisfying ending, which took me about 15-20 hours with exploration and side missions, you could tell that in some sections, the developers did not have the time to implement other features they wanted.  It's pretty obvious that they wanted to include deeper connections to Hong Kong with Wei with how much exploration and collection there were, along with Wei's serial hit-it-and-quit-it attitude with women.  Wei's struggle with his identity and corruption, both in the Triads and the police force, was a compelling reason for me to finish the story, however.

Finally, don't let the DLC scare you.  The DLC mostly adds things in to make the game a little more fun, and none of it is necessary whatsoever.  I know some people who wouldn't sneeze at Sleeping Dogs for the amount of DLC it has, but I doubt they ever actually took a look at what it does.

I really believe that Sleeping Dogs is a game that every fan of this genre should play.  Hong Kong's a relatively fresh setting from similar games, and Sleeping Dogs finds its identity in mechanics that are just fun.  Not crazy whacked up purple ♥♥♥♥♥ bat fun like Saints Row, and not maniacal, realistic Trevor fun as in GTA, but just super tight, simple, attractive combat with good pacing and a pretty beautiful world.

reviewText:
This game is awesome! I haven't been bored in this game all that time i spent there. Let's go to Pros 'n' Cons, shall we?

Pros
-Very detailed fights. You want to punch the hell outta enemies? Sure, you can fight with your bare hands or with various melees. You like gun blazin' more? Sure, grab  a gun from a cop car or buy the DLC that gives you an assault rifle in your apartment. You like to shoot people from a badass car with awesome guns on it? Buy Fury Wheels.

-Characters. I really felt for each one of them, like they were alive. I'm not giving much description here, bevlcause I don't want to spoil anything

-A crap load of clothes. Some of them give you money economy (Less money to pay) bonuses or fighting bonuses, some of them referred to Valve games. I don't really know, if you get them just for free, or you have to get the games that the clothes are referring to.

A lot of cars. From typical cars to supercars, or a supercar with miniguns in Fury Wheels. Every car is unique - the look and the characteristics.

-The unique moving car hijacking system. Yes, you heard that right - you can hijack any car, while it's on the move.

-Characters upgrades - both as triads and the police.

-Fight clubs. Easy money + kick ♥♥♥ anytime.

-Cheap DLCs
Cons
-Missions. While I liked the story, it is pretty short. There's not that much story missions tbh.

Awesome game, 9/10 - go play it, no matter - cracked game or the license, just play it. It's worth it.

I'm awaiting you in Valhalla!

It isn't like in GTA or Saints Row where you have to stop the car, get out of the car, get the other person out of the car you're trying to steal, then get in the car and drive away. In this game you simply drive behind the car, when the green arrow pops up, press a button, jump on the moving car, steal the car as its moving and drive away!

reviewText:
Has the seedy Hong Kong underworld ever called to you? Probably not, but still if you want to imagine being a Triad whilst working for the law then this is the game for you

This is a pretty awesome open world GTA style game. It is beautiful to look at and just great fun to walk around and explore. The missions are diverse and plentiful. The story is compelling and very well written. I really felt connected to the characters and invested in what happened to them. And the entire immense story was topped off by a pretty awesome finale.

Pretty much every aspect of the gameplay is solid. The driving and combat are robust and feel great. Some of my favourite memories of this game were just driving around the city at full tilt with the cops chasing me shooting out tires and running people off the road. There are a lot of vehicles and each one drives very differently.

The combat is great, so much variety and with many ways to beat the hell out of people you won’t get bored. Plus with the ability to learn more skills you will find the fighting even better the further you go. The game also feature contextual take downs, want to slam some guys face into a fan or a window? You can do that and it feels immensely satisfying

There are also tons of side missions to do such as street racing, gambling and a fight club that you will be busy for hours before even delving into the story itself. Plus with all the available DLC and now the definitive edition you will be able to delve even deeper into what Hong Kong has to offer

This version is no longer available but if I would recommend the definitive edition as it contains even more stuff. If you play this game you will have a great time, it is far superior to its spiritual predecessors and a great intro to a new series.

Have fun ^_^

PROS:
-Playable on high settings for most machines
-Fantastic gameplay
-Outstanding Story
-GTA style gameplay
-Very impressive graphics

CONS:
-not much replay-ability
-no boobs

Verdict: If you can get this for $15 or less buy it!!!!!

reviewText: Where to begin with this game. The amount of content you get is outstanding. There's cop missions, triad missions, favors, random events, tasks, hijacking, racing, gambling, hundreds of collectables, achievements, statistics, and even a silly yet charming karaoke minigame. But what really sets this game apart from the other open world gta-esk games is that this story is really compelling and interesting. I usually can't care less about the stories in these type of games - I get too distracted. But I sought out to complete this story and damn did I enjoy it.\nThe game is better than any GTA game, so if you enjoyed them you'll sure as hell enjoy this\n9/10

reviewText:
I've never played GTA. But the thought of a GTA-like game set in Asia was awesome, not enough games like this are set here.

The game world is fairly vibrant, and the art style is interesting. The gameplay is fun too, except I hated all the shooting sequences - I had to switch to the keyboard and mouse for them.

There's also a slight issue I run into if my joystick is connected as well; Sleeping Dogs for some reason ends up switching partially to the joystick and ignores the 360 controller and partly ignores the kb/mouse. I asked Square Enix support, they said it wont be fixed.

Story wise it's okay, the only slight issue I had was the number of women Wei gets to sleep with for no obvious reason at all. Reminded me a bit of The Witcher's card game.

Anyway, I had quite a bit of fun in the game.

reviewText:
Better than GTA IV.

In Sleeping Dogs your playing as Wei Shen who is an undercover cop infiltrating the Triads in Hong Kong.
This setting is way more interesting than the generic gangster setting of GTA IV or V.
You will encounter a lot of Plot Twists and intresting characters, the melee combat is a lot like the free flow system of the batman games & the driving is easy to handle and feels great.

All in all i can recommend this game to everybody who likes games like GTA but with a better story.

- Jay

reviewText:
I finally finished Sleeping Dogs yesterday and I have to say I really like the game. Nice story mode (watch Hong-Kong movie Infernal Affairs for more in-depth look on Triad) which was pretty intense, interesting side missions (still didn't finish them all), amazing graphics (especially on rainy nights), excellent sound and soundtrack. United Front Games and Square Enix didn't dissapoint.

Combat system is interesting and takes some time to used to, but when you master all kung-fu moves you'll be unstoppable (gather Jade statues as soon as you can cause it will greatly boost your performance in combat). Well, throughout the game, no matter how good you are, patience will be your biggest friend when fighting a group of mobs. :)

Don't forget to download High Resolution Texture Pack (free DLC) which will really bring the game to higher level.
Also, if you're lazy, you can purchase Top Dog Silver Pack (1,49€) and Top Dog Gold Pack (2,49€) for a quick XP boost, which will instantly give you many skillpoints to enhance your abilities and access to many wardrobe options.

Do I recommend this game? Yes, I do. It's a fun open world third person action game in the asian setting which does have some weaknesses (missions are sometimes repetative; chase enemy - kill enemy) but, all in all, it a fun game and I don't think you'll regret it.

It should be available on Steam sales for a nice price (I got it for cca 6€ a few months ago) so keep it on radar.

reviewText: I was very pleasantly surprised with Sleeping Dogs.  From the screenshots and videos I had previously seen, I expected the game to be a lot like Grand Theft Auto (Which I never really have cared for).  However, The storyline was surprisingly well built.  the game follows Wei Shen as an undercover cop infiltrating the Triads.  It deals with his conflict of wanting to stay in the gang with his new position of power and his close friend vs. his mission as a cop.  The story is intense and emotional and not at all what I expected.

reviewText:
Warning: This is NOT a GTA clone, proceed with caution

Pros
-Deep and emotional story
-Relatable Characters
-You can choose to go from Cop Missions then to Triad Missions or just roam the streets
-The Graphics
-Doesn't encourage too much gunning around
-Imaginative Executions (Meat hook, Toilet, Aquarium)
-Open World
-Parkour
-Emma Stone is in it
-Really good atmosphere
-World brought to life through Cantonese dialogue, chinese themes and traditional content
-Combat
-Voice acting is pretty good
-Its set in Hong Kong
-The amount of costumes for Wei Shen

Cons
-Graphics look ugly at some parts
-Girlfriend parts, seemed unnecessary
-Camera can be annoying at times

Overall, this game is good. Deep atmosphere, intriguing story, fun gameplay, what's not to like about it? I have to mention the driving since its been awhile since i've played this game, I honestly can't remember if it had clunky controls or smooth controls. All I can say is that the other parts of the game is amazing alone so its worth picking this game up either on full price or on sale (like a cheapie like me).

Final Verdict: 9/10
Score: Go get it!

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs is a great game that is not without its flaws but has won a place in my heart nonetheless. Once you get past the stunning visuals, you are met with an immersive underworld set in Hong Kong where an undercover officer climbs the ranks of the triads while being forced to consider his own loyalties.

Unlike other games in the genre, the combat is primarily focused on the melee aspect. Officer Shen is a very competent martial artist, and learns more moves and improves the ones he knows as the game progresses. The system feels fresh at the game's onset, but by the game's finish, it loses some of its charm. It is very visually pleasing, but from a gameplay point of view, it is very easy to master the moveset and dominate enemies under all circumstances. This does, however, propagate the sensation of being the invincible hero of the traditional asian fighting movies from which Sleeping Dogs no doubt has drawn significant amounts of inspiration.

Story-wise, the atmoshpere is great. Being in Hong Kong, people speak both English and Chinese, and you often hear the two intertwined. One of the most unusal parts was, in fact, getting used to driving primarily on the left side of the road.

You are met with a good deal of characters, some memorable even after one encounter, but many of them are unfortunately flat. This is due mostly to having too little exposure to each of them, the average being two missions for each character - one where you meet them, and one where you do them a favor of some sort. Most benefitted from interesting missions, but there were a few cases in which I felt I'd wasted my time. This deficit applies primarily to the side missions. It is worth noting that some of the side missions fall into extremes; some were very humorous and/or interesting, and some were excruciatingly boring.

Racing constitutes a major side activity, and it is decently implemented for a game that focuses on other aspects. You can purchase cars and use them in races, many of which take you through challenging routes. I often felt myself remembering the feeling I had playing Need For Speed Underground while playing through the races in the game. (It's a good feeling)

For the primary missions, the cast is built out of stereotypes, but they play their parts well and the story itself, while having some cliche elements, is pleasurable to go through and does have a few unexpected twists. Since you are a police officer in parallel to being a triad member, this opens up a series of circumstances that were especially pleasing to see playing out. The main character is also very likeable, being a smooth talker when the need arises. There are a few moments that are absolutely impossible, such as surviving a shotgun blast in close range or taking down dozens of triad cars on the street like it's nothing, but those can be forgiven since Sleeping Dogs is an action game.

The most irksome parts were getting around and going after collectibles. Getting around was immersive at first - you got to see the nooks and crannies of Hong Kong, and there were plenty of very well-detailed areas to enjoy. However, as you progress later into the game, you find yourself constantly wanting to be on the other side of the map, and with often no taxis in sight, the drive that can take several minutes gets tiring. An especially brutal offender was the naval part: getting on or off boats was extremely tiresome, primarily because of invisible walls that made it very hard to transition between sea and land.

The collectibles became annoying to deal with because many of them were placed in impossibly hard to reach positions that took ages to scout out for possible entry points. Also, you are heavily coerced into going after two of the three types of collectibles, as you need them to improve your fighting skills and health pool, both of which can pose a serious problem in the later parts of the game if ignored.

Finally, I'd like to mention the game's soundtrack. As is usual with such games, there are a number of radio stations, each catering to a different taste. I found myself enjoying several stations personally, and the commentary and advertisements between tracks were well-done and immersive.

This sums up how I feel about the game, having just finished it less than an hour ago. I mention the game's shortcomings a lot because those made the experience less enjoyable, but it was definitely a game I enjoyed overall and would recommend to others. It compensates well for what it lacks through solid mechanics, a virtual Hong Kong teeming with detail and a plot that manages to keep the player engaged from start to finish.

reviewText:
Having recently played through all the big open world games this has got to be my favourite, it really does draw you in. It does not loose focus like the saints row do(still great games though) and it has hands down the best city in an open world game, it is so alive especially at night. Does a great job of making you feel like you are in hong kong.

The story gets better and better as it goes along, it may be padded with alot of side missions but they are fun and fit the story/your character well. The characters in the game are very believable and well written and the over all story/tone of the game is of an adult nature.

I would easily rate it above watch dogs and saints row 4(two most recent open world games that take place in cities).

This was the original launch version without any of the unbalanced dlc that came later.

9/10

reviewText: This game makes no attempt to hide its influences...  The open-world criminality of GTA.  Batman's 1-vs-many melee combat.  Mirror's Edge style free-running.  Acrobatic hijackings straight out of Just Cause 2.  Cover shooting, a la Gears of War.  Innumerable cop movies and Bruce Lee movies get huge nods.  And it works.\n\nEvery idea Sleeping Dogs borrows is done less well than in the game or film that inspired it, but its success lies in the blend.  The fistfights are much better than in GTA, you go on kill-crazy rampages undreamed of in Batman, and one of the side missions is basically Enter The Dragon"

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs is probably going to be my favourite game this year. It’s hard to imagine why Activision wanted to scrap this game as it really excels well as a sandbox game and has refined how we see the genre altogether.

The story is amazing and can hold its own compared to Mafia 2 / GTA4. The combat is great, as well as movement; it’s very responsive compared to GTA4. Car’s are slightly arcade-ish to handle - but considering you can hijack cars and do slow motion shoot-outs it works out pretty well.

Overall Sleeping Dogs is a love letter to Hong Kong cinema; I’ve been mesmerized by its tiny immaculate detail which gives this game so much charisma and charm. Truly one the great gems of this generation.

On a last note, the PC version is just amazing, advance PC options and day 1 HD textures really show that United Front is committed to the PC. Listening to Ninja Tune radio while driving a motorbike down a wet and rainy neon lit sky is just pure bliss.

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs adds its name to the ever growing list of genuinely good open-world action adventure games. The melee combat focus threw me off at first, but after switching to a gaming controller, the gameplay felt significantly more intuitive over a mouse & keyboard. The intertwined story of undercover cop and bad ♥♥♥ Triad Sun On Yee Red Pole is impressively put together. Sleeping Dogs comes off every bit as an AAA title with superb graphics, voice acting, and gameplay. Plus the amazing assortment of radio stations and musical flavors is extraordinary.

Even though most of the side missions felt underwhelming, repetitive, and in many cases downright boring, I found myself continuously getting distracted trying to complete them, or stopping to seek out that next health upgrade or lockbox. I realize now it was the reward element that made them so addicting--always granting some new unlock or item reward. The taxi service is a nice feature if you want to get somewhere fast, although the car handling feels very similar to GTA San Andreas which makes driving good fun. Also the DLC adds a good variety of worthwhile content as well.

Two thumbs up.

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs is a third-person open-world game set in Hong Kong where you play as Wei Shen, an undercover cop tasked with infiltrating the Triads from his hometown from the inside. You start as a street-level enforcer and work your way into the confidences of the upper reaches of the Triads, while doing other undercover police work along the way, along with the normal extraneous missions which the game provides.

What Sleeping Dogs does, it does VERY well. It's got one of the best core stories of any open-world game that I've ever played. Its combat is top-notch (although I found it initially a little difficult to get into), at least for the hand-to-hand portion - shooting is more middle of the road. Unfortunately, the extras outside of the main storyline and the main cop assignments felt more like additions after the fact to make it an open-world game when it otherwise wouldn't really have needed to be. Car controls never felt quite /right/, but was good enough to be workable - it's only annoying in races.

All in all, the game is excellent. When the story really got going, I couldn't put it down, and it was HIGHLY satisfying. There were even one or two moments where I expected the plotline to be mildly hypocritical in favor of the protagonist and it ended up flipping my expectations on their head, which is ALWAYS appreciated.

Highly recommended.

reviewText:
I spent actual money to buy DLC for this game, that is how much I love it.

The story takes place in Hong Kong and it's your undercover cop who infiltrates a triad well known to him, and the love for his friends and his duty will be in conflict throughout the game. What elevates this story from the rest is the excellent voice acting and compelling characters that are both believeable and relateable.

The game is an open-world third-person action shooter. The combat is an improved version of the Batman: Arkham games formula, with the introduction of combos, melee weapons (like cleavers, batons and even fish!!), environmental executions and guns that, at first, feel kind of awkward, but I got used to them.
There is a lot of side activities in the world to complete: doing favors to increase fame, take part in illegal races, wipe out hidden triad gangs and sing karaoke.

The graphics are impressive, and the game really shines at night time. The city does feel alive, even though most of the pedestrians are walking or talking on a phone. The soundtrack is full of both chinese and english songs, with plenty of radio stations to choose from.

However, this game is far from perfect: the biggest complaint I have is that, when you have beaten all the story missions and favours and races, there is nothing to do. Trying to get involved in car chases with the police doesn't help since you will have upgrades that reduce heat faster than ever.

Overall, it's a fun game to spend time to, with a compelling story and many side activities, even though at the end there is nothing else to do.

SCORE: 89/100

reviewText:
I want to love Sleeping Dogs more than you can imagine. It’s colorful, spectacularly detailed, controls perfectly, it’s well optimized, the story and missions are compelling and varied, everything about it is fantastic. Sadly I just don’t enjoy brawling. Yes, there is gunplay in Sleeping Dogs (and it’s just as well executed as the rest of the game) but it takes a very definitive back seat to the martial arts combat system.

In all my years gaming the only brawling/martial arts combat game I have ever truly sunken into is the Batman franchise. The combat in Sleeping Dogs does not have quite the same fluidity as Batman but it is still very responsive and well done. To be honest, I don’t quite know why it is that Batman is fun to me but the combat in Sleeping Dogs isn’t; I don’t believe that minor difference in fluidity is the defining flaw. So it’s a brawler whose combat I dislike, no recommendation right? Wrong. Despite the backbone of the game being brawling, the game as a whole is an open world GTA style sandbox and there were so many hours of content that I absolutely loved.

If you’re not a brawling fan, Sleeping Dogs may not be something you think you would enjoy, but there is a lot there that the trailers and screenshots leave out.

reviewText:
I really enjoyed Sleeping Dogs, I spent a good hundred hours or so on it on my xbox before purchasing it on steam.

The Basics
Sleeping Dogs is an open world, third person sandbox game, set in Hong Kong. I really liked the setting of the game, as it's something different than the ususal, small things like, driving on the left side of the road made the game a bit more interesting than it would've been, should they have left details like this out. The story revolves around Wei, an undercover cop sent to take down the mafia that operates in Hong Kong.

The Gameplay
Sleeping Dogs has amazing fighting mechanics, it mostly revolves around melee combat, and guns are only used when absolutely neccesary. Because of this, Sleeping Dogs stands out from it's rivals, the melee combat is fluent, fun and never gets old. The gun mechanics are good, but nothing special or exceptional, just plain old shooting. The Melle however has a LOT of combos, and that makes for good variation, you can also execute enemies using the enviroment, giving you bonus points while finishing off an enemy in style. Driving mechanics is the only thing I dislike about this game and while you get used to them after an hour or so, they still bug me. The cars handle extremely unrealistic and I would consider that this games major flaw.

I do really like how well-optimised the game is for PC, it's an exceptional port with settings like 'world densitiy', which will determine how many pedestrians, cars etc there will be in the world.

The Graphics
Sleeping Dogs looks good, and the world feels alive and immersive, especially at night. The game's true beauty comes out when you're driving through the city at night, with all the neon lighting and advertising creating a beautiful lit up picture. So yes, this game looks good and I'm sure it'll age well.

To Summarize
+Great fighting mechanics, very refreshing melee combat.
+Good gunplay, though nothing exceptional.
+Amazing setting.
+Attention to detail.
+Graphics are really nice looking.
+Great PC-port.
-Driving mechanics leave something to be desired.

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs takes place 69 years before Watch Dogs and is supposed to be the first chinese simulator.
You play as Wei Shen, son of Fu'k-Yu Shen and Kil-Yu Shen.

Gameplay consists of doing simple tasks that chinese people have to do every day (it is, after all, a simulator): Drive badly, eat dogs, hack cameras, eat pork bun, do kung fu and plan weddings.
Your boss lives in a noodle soup kitchen and you do most of the stuff just to impress him: DON'T DISHONOL YOUR FAMIRY!

You also try to chase women but fail to get into a decent relationship.
But don't worry because there are plenty of girls who want to massage you in back alleys. - Just like real Hong Kong!

So what are you waiting for, pok gai ?! It's the best (and only) chinese simulator out there! Buy it!

reviewText:
The main storyline follows an emerging gang war that threatens to overrun the city of Hong Kong. You then follow a series of fairly redundant missions before beginning to shake down local vendors for money and beating up enemy gangs to bolster Winston's ego. Occasionally meeting up with your police handler, to hear the same lecture about not getting too emotionally involved to the monsters you’re working for.

I have to be blunt, aside from the really pretty graphics, the game takes a face dive into the floor for it's combat system being nearly non-existent. You can pretty much just sit there deflecting attacks till your enemy just spontaneously dies, since the actual combat is a bit meh by having it just be a combo of clicks. This wasn't suppose to be a point-and-click game, yet the combat system makes it feel like one. So with 80% of the game revolving around combat, it's a real let down there.

Another complaint I have to make is basically how terrible the handling of any vehicle was. There is virtually no chance of speeding and driving properly what-so-ever, as someone who has grown up playing various race games, this is another disappointing factor of the game.
The game’s second biggest issue is with its camera. It can often positions itself towards center even when you’re trying to maneuver whilst driving. This can significantly complicate navigating tight quarters or getting a look around your vehicle in open spaces. The camera can also be frustrating in some combat situations, though it doesn't happen quite as often or severely.

I also have to point out that in a gang game, it is virtually impossible to actually acquire a weapon. For memory you get a gun once during the entire game for approximately 5 minutes and nothing more. Knives are also irritatingly rare with maybe only one person in a random gang you attack to have one which you can sometimes have the option of picking up.

It redeems itself within it's story-line, but, character development, bar the ones in cut scenes seem so cut short and abnormal. You go from just meeting a person to seeming like you have been in a relationship for years. It just doesn't quite flow in my opinion.

All that aside, I did enjoy the random health shrines, deterring from the usual 'Pick up a health pot to gain more max health', within combat you can't just go to the side and chew on regenerative dirt, it takes a bit more time to actually gain it back. Another really redeeming quality is the animations to fight scenes, they are quite realistic. Also, the sounds of punching and slashing (when you finally acquire a knife) are brilliant.

Moving on.. People chattering away in the background, or random vendors trying to sell certain things to which you can also interact with a few odd ones here and there make it feel a lot more in-depth and was something I did enjoy. Also actually just having pedestrians is such a tiny detail that make a game feel so much more real. It pulls it off with flying colors. I also have to make a comment on the voice acting. It simply adds to this emphasis on realism. The game employs a unique mixture of Chinese and English that doesn't sound corny or ill-executed which can be pretty difficult to pull off.

In all, pretty good game, just a few frustrating little downfalls.

reviewText:
Technically, the game is awesome. Performs well and features plenty of eye candy. I never encountered any bugs or crashes and it supports XInput without any issues.

It's not the biggest sandbox with the most toys but what it does have are really fun to play with. :D I very nearly 100% completed this game with about 40 hours put in, all in maybe a 10 day period. I say this as a positive - while it lasted, the game really had its hooks in me.

Considering the the effort it took to even get this game released, it is excellent.

reviewText: I've heard many opinions that SD is just another GTA sandbox style clone, so I bought the game to check if this is a truth. Yeah, it's just another sanbox game, but holy sh**  - it's really good !  Graphics in the game are very eye catchy. Watching the Hong Kong at night is absolutely a great experirnce in this game. Vibrant lights, flashing signs on the streets and all other details are just beautiful. Story in the game is really good and interesting.  Gameplay mechanics are also well executed. reviewText: A game that cought me off guard, makes me want to watch Bruce Lee and Hong-Kong action movies once again. Reminds me especially of the excellent Infernal Affairs trilogy (which inspired Martin Scorcese to make The Departed), which i highly recommend you watch. Nice story, fleshed out characters, immersive Hong-Kong atmosphere. The gameplay is simple yet effective and fun to play, it also has interesting combat mechanics that forces you to use you fists and environment rather than using guns. Best part is the soundtrack, very catchy, especially the songs featured on Ninja Tune Radio. A game well worth the money and a must own for fans of hong-kong action flicks !!!

reviewText:
I am a fan of Hong Kong action movies so THIS was right up my alley.

It's not as expansive as other open world, sandbox action games but that's OK. This game has a distinct personality and gives you a very interesting narrative to play through. You feel the drama and tension between the characters. The feelz!

Combat was a bit tricky for me to pick up; it did not feel as intuitive as other games. Maybe that was their way of always keeping me on my toes?

I was hoping they would make a single-player sequel to this game but it looks like the next edition of this franchise is multiplayer.

reviewText:
1) Easy to get 100% achievement if you are willing to spend some time playing and completing it.

For DLC ( Nightmare in North Point & Year of the Snake ) achievements wait till theres a sale for the DLC and purchase them. Require about 3hours to attain all the DLC achievements.

Recommend the game, not the dlc

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs Review
Before purchasing this game, I highly recommend a good graphics card in order to furthermore enjoy the bloody scenery of this game. At first, Sleeping Dogs is joyful to play, the combat system is great, the story is adequate, the side missions are satisfactory although quite repetitive and the exploration throughout this map is wonderful.

Although,  after completing the story and the dlc's, the player feels as if he has nothing else to do, and everything else becomes quite tedious. This game is fun throughout, until the point where you have nothing to do. I highly recommend this game if you have time to kill.

reviewText:
An under-rated, open world, third person action game.  I was particularly impressed with the melee system; I'm not a fan of fighting games (can't remember all the combos) but found this to be both approachable and enjoyable.  Hong Kong has a fantastic vibe that gives it presence all it's own.  Driving has a wonderful feel of speed while still being controllable.  If you enjoy the GTA or Saints' Row series be sure to give this a shot.

Note: The bulk of my SD play was on the X360 version; I enjoyed it so much I purchased the PC version.  PC features a hi-res texture pack and is (in my opinion) the definitive version best of the original versions.  See below.

Note: The original version of SD is no longer available. The replacement is the Sleeping Dogs: Definitive Edition. It includes all the DLC, upgraded graphics, upgraded crowds and roads, etc. The game now takes advantage of current hardware to add more people to crowds, more cars to the roads, etc. 50% off for owners of the current version.

reviewText: Holy Jesus this game was so much fun. I just finished the story, and it was fantastic. I would compare the feeling I'm having right now to a roller coaster. The game was non-stop fun througout the whole game, and now I have this sudden calmness. The story was THAT great, but there was one thing I loved about it. It never bored me. I could go one mission to the next without wanting to do something else. In fact, I found the story so interesting that I have almost every secondary mission to do now that the game is over. The combat in this game is spectacular is almost exactly like Batman. The combos and way you learn them are almost identical to the game Bully however, which I noticed immediately. The driving is good for an open-world game, and smashing through everything that gets in your way is a blast. This game has been on my backlog for a while now and I highly regret it. This is the most fun I've had in a game in months. As an open-world game, I enjoyed it even more than GTA 4. 10/10.

reviewText:
Square Enix really did a fantastic job reviving this game. The sandbox open world experience of Sleeping Dogs is really well done, and they filled Hong Kong with a ton of stuff to do.

The gameplay is nothing special but it still feels great, from driving, shooting and fighting it's just really fun.

The story and characters in the game were amazingly well done, i really liked the work they did with Wei Chen, switching him from an undercover cop to a Triad member and reveal how it affects his life and those around him.

The graphics are some of the most beautiful i've ever seen in a game, i was really impressed with the light filled streets of Hong Kong, the shiny cars on rainy days or just a normal day.

A great game overall, it's worth every cent.

reviewText:
Grand Theft Auto: China.

That's almost a dead accurate representation of what this game is. Although you play a cop and not just some vigilante going home or starting out a crime bid. Other than that it's pretty much Grand Theft Auto.

You run can around the City scape looking for Cars, Money Boxes, Red Envolopes, Statues, and occationally Call up some chicks so you can have dates with them.

The Main Weapon of this game is your Fists, there is no weapon cycling, you either have a weapon or you don't and chances are you will not have a weapon on you when an enemy pulls one out so you have to rely on your own disarming abilities to get the upper hand and thankfully the game gives you power ups to improve your abilities in hand to hand combat making fighting much easier and fun.

Also the Fighting mechanics are pretty much ripped straight off of The Arkham Games, so if you're pretty keen on that you're pretty much set with this game.

Overall Sleeping Dogs is a great experience. I really like the atmosphere of this game and it gets really easy to get lost in this game just by driving around or walking around and just taking in the whole Chiniese experience.

This is worth a buy.

reviewText:
A very good game.

The star of the game is obviously Hong-Kong itself. I have no idea if it bears any ressemblance to the real city, but Hong-Kong in Sleeping Dogs is a town bustling with life, with shops everywhere and citizens going about their business. It feels like an actual place where people live, rather than a succession of hotspots for a player to experience like you find in other sandbox games. For someone not native to an Asian culture, it's also a very attractive jump into a different culture.

As for the gameplay, it's solid. The car handling is great, and it's a real pleasure to drive around the city, just for fun. The melee fight, though somewhat limited, is still satisfying, especially after you get a few upgrades that allow you to fight like you want. As for the gunfight, it's extremely fun, especially the action scenes when you're gunning down enemies while in a car. It feels like an HK-action film.

However, the game is not perfect. The story is servicable, but not much more. It's somewhat disjointed here and there, and not believable at all. There are also a few things that lack polish, like the Car Valet system which fail you regularly for unknown reasons, or the taxi system, which use the same button as the car thief, making for some awkward mistakes. Theses are small things, but they do add up, and that's something you wouldn't find in Saint Rows III or GTA IV (even though i dislike that game). Finally, the game is too easy, with no way to customize the difficulty, which is somewhat sad for people looking for a challenge.

On the whole, the game provides a very nice experience, especially if you enjoy the Asian setting. But in the heavy weight category of open-city sandboxes, its few misteps make it falls down a notch compared to games like Arkham City (which has a much better melee combat), or Saint Rows III (which has more variety and polish). Still if you like the open-world genre, you will not regret buying Sleeping Dogs.

reviewText:
Another day in Hong Kong...

From the creator's of the 'True Crime' series comes 'Sleeping Dogs' a third person, open-world game.

Plot is quite engaging. You play as a undercover cop Wei Shen, who is tasked with infiltrating a ruthless Hong Kong crime syndicate. You will meet a wide range of memorable characters as you try to balance your loyalties between the triads and the police.

Gameplay is quite good. Similar to GTA, you have an open world to explore with a vast range of activities. The city of Hong Kong is split into three areas, which are basically smaller cities. There are main quests that are available and accessable at your free will, as well as side quests scattered around the city. Besides combat, there are other activities to partcipate in such as ♥♥♥♥ fight betting, street racing, brawling, buying food, clothing etc. Unlike GTA and Saints Row, weapons can't be purchased and need to be obtained from certain areas or fallen enemies. Although you are an undercover cop, you are free to shoot/ram civilians to your pleasure, but be prepared to face the Hong Kong law enforcement (which gets stronger and more persistsant as your crime spree increases, like GTA). There is also an upgrade system in place which allows you to gain new moves, more health etc through gaining experience from playing the game. You also have a health bar (that regenerates when in cover), which when depleted, will make you spawn at a hospital. Beside the usual guns such as pistols, shotguns etc melee combat plays a major role in the game. You can grab and throw enemies, smash enemies against walls, counter melee attacks and use elements of the environment (e.g. saw) to dispose of foes.  Gun play does play a role in this game with cover, slow time mechanics, although they aren't that spectacular. The main enemies you will be facing are gun guys, while others will be going at you melee style with fists, knives, bats etc. There are also a variety of vehicles available including cars, bikes, vans and boats (no flying vehicles though).

Audio is great. Voice actors sound excellent and believeable. Background music does a great job at setting the asian atmosphere.

Grapahics are quite decent as well. Thanks to the free 'High Resolution Texture' DLC, buildings and the overall environment looks beautiful. Although the main characters  also look good, regular NPC's don't look that great.

If you're tired of playing open world games set in America (ie. GTA and Saints Row), Sleeping Dogs is a breath of fresh air.

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs provides the player to be a part of undercover cop with strong and engrossing narrative set in open-world. Once again, it is always compared to GTA-like games, but Sleeping Dogs has proved itself to be high potential sandbox. The production is easily noticeable; plot, voice acting, and environment are simply amazing. The cities are highly detailed and full of NPCs walking around and perform their activities based on situation. If Kane and Lynch: Dog Days takes player to the darkest side of China, then Sleeping Dogs will bring player to richly-detailed and diverse environment in Hong Kong from the old slums and night market to the business districts.

The gameplay is another strong point. The main missions are pretty diverse and well connect to the storyline. The game offers you many types of mini-game like plant a bug, picklock, cracking safe which give you feeling of being undercover cop. Martial arts is easy to learn and achieve as you proceed through the game, you will unlock more fighting style to beat different types of enemy; knock, stun, combo, and environment kills give a very satisfied outcome and well entertained. The gunplay has simple mechanics; fire behind cover or slide on object to activate slow-motion (like a John Woo’s films). Both running chase scenes and driving are well-made for badass feeling like shooting tires to take down enemy vehicles or hijack vehicle and continue your road carnage. Moreover, the ramming mechanics during driving is simply useful as you can use it to lose the cops or even boost your speed in race. Sleeping Dogs also rewards player in every mission and collectables which keep on player engagement and provide meaningful collectable. However, the side mission is quite less creative and combat is quite sluggish. Still, there is a lot of detail and things to do even you complete the game.

Lastly, the radio music is memorable with old Chinese song and some are from famous singer. The mixture of voice between pure Cantonese and English dub create the feel of player’s presence and preserve what Hong Kong should be.
Sleeping Dogs is unique and diverse as I said. The developers care in most details and know what keep on player engagement. It gives me very great experience to be part of Hong Kong and triad life. I never regret for every buck I spend on this game. Like it or not, you have to taste once.

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs is a great game, not perfect in anyway, but it's still a good experience.

Graphics:
There good, not the best but the game has a few years on it now. For AMD users like myself, this game is a pleasue, runs so well it's unbelieveable. I run this game 100fps+ maxed and it does look very nice. Graphics are good enough, not much pop-in which is fantastic and people faces look quite nice.

Story:
Story is alright, it's not the best or the worst. Looking past some of it's major flaws and loop wholes, it serves it's purpose. I wouldn't buy this game for it's story alone though, you need to enjoy the mechanics aswell. Being a double agent puts a nice spin on things, but it's nothing we haven't seen before. Lots of twists are predictable sadly, and slow turn of cop into bad guy is very generic.

Mechanics:
Hand to Hand combat is beautiful, it's so rare to find a game like this that focuses on close combat instead of guns. Really enjoyed it,  very smooth and the counter system is nice. Only problem is it's a little to easy, especially when you can kill everybody except bosses and grapplers by throwing them into a phonebooth.

Overall:
Good game, probably one of the best open world titles left that people haven't played. It's no GTA, but it's great to fill that gap while waiting for something else. Game is quite shoot, however, keep in mind I didn't do any sidemissions. I went straight through all the main missions.

Nice game, would definitely recommend on sale.
Rating: 7/10

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs is about an undercover police agent in Hong Kong. Your task is going to be to infiltrate one of the Triad's factions and work with your HKPD colleagues. That's the main storyline
In itself this may not sound any new... BUT:
- the game environment is simply stunning, you literally feel yourself in Hong Kong
- the free running part of the game is also a great idea
- beside the main storyline the game offers you tenth if not hundreds of hours of gameplay, not even counting the DLCs
- the characters sometimes speak Cantonese (the local Hong Kong language) which adds a totally new layer to the in game feeling

I am usually do not back to a title after I finished it but with Sleeping Dogs I literally ran through the main storyline just so that  I can now how it ends and can start a new game in which I can focus on everything else not the main storyline.

The only negative thing may be the stupig behavior of some vehicles (cars, motorbikes, boats) in the game... You'll find yourself crushing into other objects if you are very careful on your controls.

Overall, I think it is must have for anyone who is into the TPS, RPG titles.

Buy this game.  Everything about this is so much fun.  It's a 3rd person action game (think GTA) set in Hong Kong.  Have you bought this game yet?
The hand to hand combat is great, the shooting mechanics aren't bad, the driving is insanely good on motorcycle/car the graphics are gorgeous with HD textures.

There is a lot of extra stuff for you to do in addition to the main story that can take you all around the city.

There is a level up process that gets you stronger fighting abilities in addition to other abilities (like the ability to slow down time so it's easier to jump from a car to another car) and stuff like that.
Saving the DLC for later this year when it's more appropriate (Halloween).

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs is ruff (geddit?), but it's worth playing.

The melee combat is a plus, but it takes some time to get into the swing of things.  Combos work with permutations of tap and hold.  A bit of lag and lack of knowledge about the frames can lead to frustrating defeat.  By the end, it was moot due to both my experience and the fact that my upgrades filled in erroneous button presses with new moves.  I went from dreading combat to enjoying it a lot.

I even found the racing tolerable.  It's perhaps even enjoyable.  I avoid racing games and loathe racing segments in open world games so this was a pleasant surprise.  Granted, quick sessions and the ability to slam cars away helps. ;)

Despite the quantity of DLC, the game could still use some polish and at times seems unfinished.  What can and can't be jumped over often feels arbitrary. The wayward GPS may add realism, but it's inconvenient.   Towards the end, there was an important conversation which got cut off near a waypoint and sent me into a rage as I witnessed umpteen YouTubers do the same. Earlier, there was even an optional mission with a conversation hinting at a prior, nonexistent event.

However, I can look past all of that.

The main problem is built into the game design.  Missions are graded, and unlocked abilities are based on those scores.  While the missions can be replayed, their prior reward is subtracted from their new one so there's no way to grind.  For the Triad, you have to either do extremely well or buy some special DLC.  Adding RPG elements just to replace them with a feedback loop for arcade perfectionists doesn't sit well with me.

I'm the kind of guy who likes to earn everything BEFORE finishing the story and then walk away with good memories of the credits rolling. Having already beaten the game and replayed missions to being just a fraction away from my final upgrade, I finally decided to just move on.

Fortunately, it was fun while it lasted.  I might pick up some DLC sometime when it goes on sale again.




Thank you for the giveaway, GameHounds! =)  http://www.gamehounds.net/

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs is GTA 4 with parkour and good combat and bullet-time. That's it really. It's GTA 4 mashed up with Hong Kong cinema. It's pretty glorious.

The combat in this game is really just a simplified Arkham Asylum, which is pretty ♥♥♥♥ing good for a GTA clone, considering how wrong they always get it. You've got pretty simple X, X, X, hold X combos, with different amount of X's pre-hold giving you different sweet combos. You've got a grapple that you can follow up with arm-breaking, tossing them off a ledge, or just, you know, bashin' their face in. You have all sorts of sweet kicks. It's pretty martial-artsy of course but it's less trying to look cool (although it does) and more about no nonsense killing dudes with your body. Also you can grab people and throw them in dumpsters or impale them on meat hooks or smash them into a box full of broken glass (yeah I don't know why there are boxes full of broken glass everywhere.)

The driving feels good, but I can't remember how driving felt in GTA 4. It probably apes that as well so if you're one of those ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s who couldn't deal with that you'll probably hate it. But you can hang out of your car window and shoot out tires and ♥♥♥♥ and when you start shooting the game goes into slow motion so you can actually do it without crashing into a wall, which is cool. This is a pretty spergy thing, but I really like the freeway system in this game. It loops around the whole city with lots of nice on-ramps and exchanges everywhere and apparently I love that ♥♥♥♥ because I like just getting on the freeway and going fast.

This game has ♥♥♥♥loads of bullet-time. You punch a guy with your gun out? Aim your gun after and you get some bullet-time. Vault over your cover? Aim your gun and guess what? ♥♥♥♥in' bullet-time. Headshot 3 guys before you land, it's awesome.Oh yeah, and you can jump out of your car and onto another car and steal it in motion. That ♥♥♥♥ owns, so do that a bunch.

The story is ok, I guess. It's serviceable at least. You're an undercover cop in with the triads, and guess what, spoiler alert, you get too close to your gangster buddies and loyalties get conflicted. You're way too good at what you do and kill a billion people so you end up promoted to the top of the organization way too fast. You know, standard stuff. I am pretty curious how you end up getting off scot-free after how many people you've killed. The Hong Kong PD are pretty ♥♥♥♥ing corrupt, I guess. Well they are cops. ACAB

Oh, and if you're a sperglord like me, it puts all the collectibles on the minimap. Thank ♥♥♥♥ing god. For some reason they unlock after you bone down on the various women you encounter throughout the story. I think Wei ♥♥♥♥s just about every woman he encounters. So I guess that's cool, or troubling, maybe. I can't decide. I guess his karaoke powers and street fighting skillz are just enough to overlook the ridiculous clothing he's (probably) wearing.

Time to wait for the DLC to go on sale.

reviewText: Sleeping Dogs is an open world action-adventure video game developed by United Front Games and Square Enix London. The game has you infiltrating the ranks of the Triads as undercover cop Wei Shen on an island off the mainland of Hong Kong.\n\nSleeping Dogs places a strong emphasis on hand to hand combat giving you the opportunity to unlock a wide range of different combos to be used while fighting. The combat very closely resembles that of Batman: Arkham City however doesn't feel as smooth, regardless anyone who enjoyed that series will probably enjoy this.

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs Review
Before purchasing this game, I highly recommend a good graphics card in order to furthermore enjoy the bloody scenery of this game. At first, Sleeping Dogs is joyful to play, the combat system is great, the story is adequate, the side missions are satisfactory although quite repetitive and the exploration throughout this map is wonderful.

Although,  after completing the story and the dlc's, the player feels as if he has nothing else to do, and everything else becomes quite tedious. This game is fun throughout, until the point where you have nothing to do. I highly recommend this game if you have time to kill.

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs is the best open world game I have ever played. The world is large and urban. The open-world, fighting system, graphics, and sound are extremely solid. But that is not what I am here for.

I am here to praise this game on the most amazing story I have ever experienced behind SC:BW. The writers hook you to the well-paced story and connects you deeply with the characters on a emotional level. I cried multiple times throughout this plot that deeply connected me with every character and their motives.

All-in-all, this is an extremely underatted game that everyone should play, my only issue is the singleplayer not being longer, and my only regret is uninstalling the game.

reviewText:
Square Enix really did a fantastic job reviving this game. The sandbox open world experience of Sleeping Dogs is really well done, and they filled Hong Kong with a ton of stuff to do.

The gameplay is nothing special but it still feels great, from driving, shooting and fighting it's just really fun.

The story and characters in the game were amazingly well done, i really liked the work they did with Wei Chen, switching him from an undercover cop to a Triad member and reveal how it affects his life and those around him.

The graphics are some of the most beautiful i've ever seen in a game, i was really impressed with the light filled streets of Hong Kong, the shiny cars on rainy days or just a normal day.

A great game overall, it's worth every cent.

reviewText:
Dear Reader,
Sleeping Dogs is a spectactular game.
With a lovely story where everyone is happy and they gets what they want, it makes for a truely realistic experience of what it is like being a man living in Hong Kong. In Sleeping Dogs, there is no violence or drama, but it makes up for that with lots of heartfelt, family-friendly humor. I have personally put almost 24 hours worth of my time into this game, and I do intend to put more. So, if you do get bored with your mindless slaughter of innocent NPC's, purchase and enjoy Sleeping Dogs today.

Love,
Fossor_

reviewText:
I am eating pork buns and curried fish balls with noodles while I write this review. Bet that doesn't happen every day.

This game is so much better than most of the Metacritic reviews would lead you to believe. Way better than GTA 4 overall. There are a lot of GTA elements in here, like the car jumps, but it is way different. I fianally got this game and have played non-stop for two days. The ablity to be a bad ♥♥♥ martial arts character and beat the fish balls off of bad guys is what puts it over the top. Nothing like this in GTA even comes close.

At first the controls and driving are a bit hard to figure out and get used too. Once you get a few hours into the game it will start to flow and become like an action movie. Reminds me so much of the 80's Hong Kong action movies . Almost perfect in that respect, where you feel like Chow Yun Fat in Triads: The Inside Story.

If you love open-world games like GTA and especially Saints Row 3, then you will love this game. My advice is to get the high-rez pack and the play through once without any of the extra DLC. You get a nice little starter boost with the Digital Edition so you should experience the game without anything else the first time.

I just finished one play-through (all cops and triad missions and favors) so now I am going back and doing it all over with the DLCs included. This game is that good that I am completely addicted to it like I was when GTA San Andreas first hit.

You can easily rack up over 100 hours if you explore the whole city and do all the extra missions and find the collectables. I have seen a lot of people complain that there is only about 20 hours of play, but that is only if you rush through and just do the main story line.

I would have to give this game 9.5 pork buns for my overall score. The only reason I don't give it a ten is the slight difficulty with the controls and interface.

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs is a great game, not perfect in anyway, but it's still a good experience.

Graphics:
There good, not the best but the game has a few years on it now. For AMD users like myself, this game is a pleasue, runs so well it's unbelieveable. I run this game 100fps+ maxed and it does look very nice. Graphics are good enough, not much pop-in which is fantastic and people faces look quite nice.

Story:
Story is alright, it's not the best or the worst. Looking past some of it's major flaws and loop wholes, it serves it's purpose. I wouldn't buy this game for it's story alone though, you need to enjoy the mechanics aswell. Being a double agent puts a nice spin on things, but it's nothing we haven't seen before. Lots of twists are predictable sadly, and slow turn of cop into bad guy is very generic.

Mechanics:
Hand to Hand combat is beautiful, it's so rare to find a game like this that focuses on close combat instead of guns. Really enjoyed it,  very smooth and the counter system is nice. Only problem is it's a little to easy, especially when you can kill everybody except bosses and grapplers by throwing them into a phonebooth.

Overall:
Good game, probably one of the best open world titles left that people haven't played. It's no GTA, but it's great to fill that gap while waiting for something else. Game is quite shoot, however, keep in mind I didn't do any sidemissions. I went straight through all the main missions.

Nice game, would definitely recommend on sale.
Rating: 7/10

reviewText: On the plus side, the story is excellent, the scenery is lovely (I'm tempted to say I now understand why Vancouver looks the way it does ;) and the driving is pretty confident. On the uneven to negative side, the missions, while imaginatively framed, aren't very hard, and there's too much of the rather routine melee fighting. By the back third of the game I was feeling a bit bored, although I saw it through. A shame: a missed opportunity to really go to town in an excellent environment. But it's a little too polite.

reviewText:
This totally surprised me. Honk Kong is great place for sandbox game, and map is quite damn large. Game is mostly based on melee combat, but you'll also have weapons later in game. Melee system is great, it has lots of different moves to learn.

Game has lots of vehicles, motorcycles and cars. You can steal any car from street as you should, or you can pay taxidriver to take you where you want if you're too lazy to drive yourself, and then rob his car. Most cars are fast, and pretty easy to control. You can buy yourself cars, which will be added to garage.

Storyline is about undercover cop, if someone did not know that, it is interesting, but nothing spectacular. Sound acting is in  English, and some Chinese phrases are part of it.

Game has about 20 hours of gameplay, which also includes some of collectibles.

I was interested in this game, and decided to buy it when it was on sale.

I do not regret buying it, it is great game, one of my favorites in 2012.

reviewText:
I fell in love with this game the first time I played it. I'd been on the fence regarding buying it since I'd heard a few detractors saying it wasn't as good as GTA.
I love the GTA series, but this tops them. Why? Because not only the story is good, but also the fighting mechanic - GTA was never good at fighting, it was all about driving and shooting. Sleeping Dogs brings in the Arkham series' style of freeflow fighting (though not as good as the Arkham games, it's not far off) as well as cool things like being able to jump from one car to another to hijack vehicles, take hostages, have bullet time vault shootings and much more.

The game is 2 years old but still looks as good, if not better (at times), than Watch Dogs. It runs really well, too. I was able to run it at ultra settings the day it came out, even with the hi-res PC-only texture pack that was released. Nowadays, I can run it at 2880x1620 (and would expect to run it at 4k, if my monitor supported it).

If you've been disappointed by Watch Dogs, then give this a try - I personally find it's more fun than Watch Dogs, allows you to interact with the other people in the environment more and has a great fighting system. It doesn't have all the hacking stuff, and is more action-orientated than stealth based, but that's not always a bad thing in the open world genre.

reviewText: Imagine, if you will, a world in which Square Enix put Grand Theft Auto, Batman: Arkham City, and Jackie Chan into a blender. That's what this game is.
